item.title: Noun Types
item.description: The type decides the declension rules (not derivation) for ± morphemes. P-nouns: -p in Relative arnaq: -p ukioq (year), ukiup (year’s), ukiut (years) BUT does not apply to derivation UP-nouns: +/-up in Relative Whether it is + or - varies from noun to noun -fik: +up -suaq: -up -innaq: +up eqqumiitsuliortoq±mi: (p noun) eqqumiitsuliortumi (uses -mi, not +mi) Note: Schwa is not orthographically marked and is disappearing.

item.title: Gemination
item.description: Word ending with -gaq, -raq, -seq, -leq, -iak, -iaq like meeraq, oqaaseq, kalaaleq, double the stem consonant when taking an ending: oqaatimik, meerramik (but not when being derived: oqaatiinnaq) meeraq -nik -> meeqqanik meeraq -nut -> meeqqanut atuagaq -it -> atuakkat taseq -it -> tatsit

item.title: Plural
item.description: plural of p-nouns: -t plural of p-nouns: -it +it (mixed) let vocbase = [ ["atuagaq (book)", "atuakkat"], ["meeraq (child)", "meeqqat"], ["taseq (lake)", "tatsit"], ["kikiat (nail)", "kikissat (j is geminated)"], ["imaq (ocean)", "immat"], ["erneq (son)", "ernerit"], ["angut (man)", "angutit"], ["arnaq (woman)", "arnat"], ["orpik (tree)", "orpiit"], ["assak (hand)", "assaat"], ["illu (house)", "illut"], ["inuk (human)", "inuit"] ]; Test Yourself Switch Answer

item.title: Cases
item.description: Relative: similar to Genitive; expresses ’s and s’: singular: p-nouns arnaq -> arnap ukioq -> ukiup up-nouns take ±up (-up for the mixed?) -fik: +up suaq: -up innaq: +up plural: p-nouns: -t up-nouns: ±it Absolutive: the subjects of intransitive verbs or the objects of transitive verbs N±it (up nouns)/N-t (p nouns) N-kka: Ns of mine (my N’s; meeqqakka) N-ga: N of mine (my N; meeraara) N-a: N of its (its N) N-at: N of theirs (their N, Kalaallit nunaAT) ~~~~~~ Anaana (Absolutive) oqarpoq: Grandma is subject.
